description: From Middle English declaren, from Old French declarer, from Latin dēclārō (“to make clear”), from dē- + clārus (“clear”).

verbs.description: declare (third-person singular simple present declares, present participle declaring, simple past and past participle declared)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To make clear, explain, interpret.
examples: To declare this a little, we must assume that the surfaces of all such bodies  […]  are exactly smooth.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To assert or announce formally, officially, explicitly, or emphatically.
examples: Synonyms: disclose, make known; see also Thesaurus:announce

entries.meaning: (card games) To show one's cards in order to score.
(intransitive, cricket) For the captain of the batting side to announce the innings complete even though all batsmen have not been dismissed.
(intransitive, politics) For a constituency in an election to officially announce the result
examples: Houghton and Sunderland South was the first constituency to declare in the 2015 general election.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To inform government customs or taxation officials of goods one is importing or of income, expenses, or other circumstances affecting one's taxes.
examples: The prosecution has introduced evidence, including canceled checks, to show that the judge failed to declare part of his income.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make outstanding debts, e.g. taxes, payable.
(transitive, programming) To explicitly establish the existence of (a variable, function, etc.) without necessarily describing its content.
examples: The counter "i" was declared as an integer.
